questions.text: What is the typical stroke volume in a resting 70 Kg man?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)

Stroke volumes range from 55-100ml.

choices.text: Up to 95% of filtered amino acids will be reabsorbed at this site
It is a risk of damage in a patient with compartment syndrome due to a tibial fracture
It is responsible for absorbing more than 50% of filtered water
Its secretory function is most effective at low systolic blood pressures (typically less than 100mmHg)
Glucose is reabsorbed by combined active and passive (facilitated diffusion processes)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of the proximal convoluted tubule in the kidney?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The proximal convoluted tubule may undergo necrosis in situations such as compartment syndrome. It is responsible for reabsorbing up to two thirds of filtered water. Low systolic blood pressures (below the renal autoregulatory range) are a risk factor for acute tubular necrosis. Within the autoregulatory range the absolute value of systolic BP has little effect. The process of facilitated diffusion of glucose refers to its co-transport with sodium.

questions.text: Which main group of receptors does dobutamine bind to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Dobutamine is a sympathomimetic with both alpha- and beta-agonist properties; it displays a considerable selectivity for beta1-cardiac receptors.


Phosphodiesterase inhibitors such as milrinone act specifically on the cardiac phosphodiesterase and increase cardiac output.

choices.text: Glucagon is produced in response to hyperglycaemia
Produced in response to an increase of amino acids
Composed of 2 alpha polypeptide chains linked by hydrogen bonds

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true of glucagon?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Glucagon is a protein comprised of a single polypeptide chain. Produced by alpha cells of pancreatic islets of Langerhans in response to hypoglycaemia and amino acids. It increases plasma glucose and ketones

choices.text: It stimulates pancreatic acinar cells to release lipase

questions.text: Which of the following is not an effect of somatostatin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

It inhibits pancreatic enzyme secretion.

questions.text: Which of the following stimulates gastric acid secretion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Gastrin: From G cells: stimulates gastric acid production

Pepsin: Digestion of protein, secretion occurs simultaneously with gastrin

Secretin: From mucosal cells in the duodenum and jejunum: inhibits gastric acid, stimulates bile and pancreatic juice production

Gastric inhibitory peptide: (produced in response to fatty acids) inhibits gastrin release and acid secretion from parietal cells

Cholecystokinin: From mucosal cells in the duodenum and jejunum (produced in response to fatty acids) inhibits acid secretion from parietal cells, causes gallbladder contraction and relaxation of sphincter of Oddi

Somatostatin: From D cells

Histamine released from enterochromaffin like cells then stimulates the acid-making cells (parietal cells) in a paracrine manner to increase gastric acid production.

questions.text: Which of the substances below is derived primarily from the zona reticularis of the adrenal gland?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

choices.text: Inhibition of thyroid stimulating hormone release
Increased degradation of T4 within the thyroid colloid
Increased degradation of T3 within the thyroid colloid
Inhibits release of T3 and T4 into the circulation

questions.text: A 28 year old lady with hyperthyroidism is started on carbimazole to treat the condition. What is the main mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)

Carbimazole is used to treat hyperthyroidism. Carbimazole is a pro-drug as after absorption it is converted to the active form, methimazole. Methimazole prevents thyroid peroxidase enzyme from iodinating and coupling the tyrosine residues on thyroglobulin, hence reducing the production of the thyroid hormones T3 and T4. Clinical effects take some months to occur as thyroid globulin stores remain for some time after treatment commences.

questions.text: A 56 year old man underwent a truncal vagotomy operation many years ago. The direct release of which of these hormones will be most affected as a result?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)

Motilin is released by the small bowel in response to alkaline contents in the duodenum/ jejunum and increases the migrating motor complexes in the small bowel.

Cholecystokinin, secretin and GIP are all released in response to changes in the luminal contents. Gastrin is released from G cells and whilst the luminal contents affect its release, it is also directly released in response to vagal stimuli.

questions.text: Which of the following features does not put a patient at risk of refeeding syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Diuretics increase the risk of re-feeding syndrome through a process of increasing the risk of depletion of key electrolytes.

questions.text: A 73 year old lady is recovering from recent surgery and is resting. Whilst she is resting, which of these muscles will be the major contributor to ventilatory activity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The diaphragm is the major muscle involved in this process and it is for this reason that diminished activity following major abdominal surgery (note surgery type not specified here) can result in atelectasis.

choices.text: In parietal cells carbonic anhydrase generates hydrogen ions which are then actively secreted
The cephalic phase is abolished following truncal vagotomy
The intestinal phase accounts for 60% of gastric acid produced
Histamine acts in a paracrine manner on H2 receptors
H2 receptor antagonists will not completely abolish gastric acid production

questions.text: Which of the following statements relating to gastric acid secretions are untrue?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The intestinal phase of gastric acid secretion accounts for only 10% of gastric acid produced.

questions.text: In a biopsy taken from the gastro intestinal tract, where is a Paneth cell most likely to be identified?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Paneth cells are secretory cells located in the crypts of Lieberkuhn. They are an important contributor to the gut microbiome and have roles in host defence and immunity.

questions.text: The blood - brain barrier is not highly permeable to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)

The blood brain barrier is relatively impermeable to highly dissociated compounds.

questions.text: A 34 year old man receives morphine following an appendicectomy. He develops constipation as a result. Which of the following best accounts for this process?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

4 Types of opioid receptor:

• δ (located in CNS)- Accounts for analgesic and antidepressant effects

• k (mainly CNS)- analgesic and dissociative effects

• Âµ (central and peripheral) - causes analgesia, miosis, decreased gut motility

• Nociceptin receptor (CNS)- Affect of appetite and tolerance to Âµ agonists.

Constipation is a common side effect of morphine treatment and stimulation of Mu receptors accounts for this process.

questions.text: Which of the following agents increases the rate of emptying of the vagotomised stomach?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Erythromycin increases the rate of gastric emptying and decreases GI transit times in general. This accounts for its side effect profile (diarrhea). It can be a useful agent in diabetic gastropathy

choices.text: Anterior horn of L5 nerve roots
Anterior horn of S2 nerve roots

questions.text: A 43 year old lady presents with urinary incontinence. At which of the following locations is Onufs nucleus likely to be found?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Onufs nucleus is located in the anterior horn of S2 and is the origin of neurones to the external urethral sphincter.

choices.text: Increase in the rate of gastric emptying

questions.text: Release of somatostatin from the pancreas will result in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Octreotide reduces exocrine pancreatic secretions so is used to treat high output pancreatic fistulae (though parenteral feeding is most effective). Other uses include variceal bleeding and treatment of acromegaly.

Inhibits growth hormone and insulin release (when released from pancreas). Somatostatin is also released by the hypothalamus causing a negative feedback response on growth hormone.

questions.text: A 56 year old man has long standing chronic pancreatitis and develops pancreatic insufficiency. Which of the following will be absorbed normally?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pancreatic lipase is required for digestion of fat, Proteases facilitate protein and B12 absorption. Folate digestion is independent of the pancreas

questions.text: A 23 year old man is undergoing an inguinal hernia repair under local anaesthesia. The surgeon encounters a bleeding site which he manages with diathermy. About a minute or so later the patient complains that he is able to feel the burning pain of the heat at the operative site. Which of the following nerve fibres is responsible for the transmission of this signal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Slow transmission of mechanothermal stimuli is transmitted via C fibres. A γ fibres transmit information relating to motor proprioception, A β fibres transmit touch and pressure and B fibres are autonomic fibres.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is released from the sympathetic nervous system to stimulate the adrenal medulla?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

In the autonomic nervous system, noradrenaline is the commonly used neurotransmitter. However, in the adrenal medulla, Acetylcholine is released to stimulate adrenaline release.

questions.text: A 24 year old man is injured in a road traffic accident. He becomes oliguric and his renal function deteriorates. Which of the options below would favor acute tubular necrosis over pre renal uraemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

In acute tubular necrosis there is no response to intravenous fluids because the damage occurs from within the renal system rather than as a result of volume depletion.

questions.text: Which is the least likely to cause hyperuricaemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Mnemonic of the drugs causing hyperuricaemia as a result of reduced excretion of urate

'Can't leap'

C iclosporin

A lcohol

N icotinic acid

T hiazides

L oop diuretics

E thambutol

A spirin

P yrazinamide

Decreased tubular secretion of urate occurs in patients with acidosis (eg, diabetic ketoacidosis, ethanol or salicylate intoxication, 
starvation ketosis). The organic acids that accumulate in these conditions compete with urate for tubular secretion.

choices.text: Formation of IgG antibodies to the TSH receptors on the thyroid gland
Formation of IgG antibodies to the TRH receptors on the anterior pituitary
Formation of IgM antibodies to the TSH receptors on the thyroid gland
Formation of IgA antibodies to the TSH receptors on the thyroid gland
Formation of IgM antibodies to the TRH receptors on the anterior pituitary

questions.text: A 22 year old lady presents with symptoms and signs of hyperthyroidism. Her diagnostic work up results in a diagnosis of Graves disease. Which of these statements best describes the pathophysiology of the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Usually IgG antibodies are formed against the TSH receptors on the thyroid gland. Which is why the TSH level is often very low in Graves disease

questions.text: Which one of the following is associated with increased lung compliance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Emphysema

questions.text: A 23 year old woman presents with severe headache, photophobia and neck stiffness. A lumbar puncture is undertaken and cerebrospinal fluid is sent for microscopy and culture. Culture shows a growth of Neisseria meningitidis. What is likely to be the predominant cell type in the cerebrospinal fluid?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)

In bacterial meningitis, neutrophils are typically present in the CSF. In viral meningitis, a lymphocytosis is said to predominate. Clinically, there can be overlap with a neutrophilia occurring in some cases of viral meningitis. In bacterial meningitis, the neutrophilia can be attenuated by the administration of antibiotics.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not positively inotropic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Inotropes are a class of drugs that increase the force or cardiac contractility. This may improve cardiac output. Increased blood pressure may have direct beneficial effects for the heart in that it improves myocardial perfusion pressure. Dopamine and dobutamine are both commonly used inotropes, they should be administered via a central line and in a monitored setting. Glucagon and theophylline are also positive inotropes (although not commonly used for this purpose). In contrast sodium thiopentone causes marked myocardial depression.

questions.text: A 54 year old lady has her serum calcium measured. Assuming her renal function is normal, what proportion of calcium filtered at the glomerulus will be reabsorbed by the renal tubules?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)

Most filtered calcium is reabsorbed (95%) a rare disorder of familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia may affect this proportion.

questions.text: A 65 year old man is admitted for a below knee amputation. He is taking digoxin. Clinically the patient has an irregularly irregular pulse. What would you expect to see when you examine the jugular venous pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)

Jugular venous pressure

Absent a waves = Atrial fibrillation
Large a waves = Any cause of right ventricular hypertrophy, tricuspid stenosis Cannon waves (extra large a waves) = Complete heart block
Prominent v waves = Tricuspid regurgitation
Slow y descent = Tricuspid stenosis, right atrial myxoma
Steep y descent = Right ventricular failure, constrictive pericarditis, tricuspid regurgitation
This patient has atrial fibrillation and is most likely to have absent a waves.

choices.text: Potassium levels unchanged, sodium levels increased
Potassium levels raised sodium levels unchanged

questions.text: A person is diagnosed with Conns syndrome. If the parotid gland secretions were assayed, what change (if any) will be noted?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Aldosterone affects the parotid gland secretions and has the effect of conserving sodium (so salivary sodium reduced) and potassium secretion increased

questions.text: Which of the following does not stimulate insulin release?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Beta blockers inhibit the release of insulin. Stimulation of insulin release:

• Glucose

• Amino acid

• Vagal cholinergic

• Secretin/Gastrin/CCK

• Fatty acids

• Beta adrenergic drugs

questions.text: A 28 year old man is shot in the abdomen and haemorrhages. Which of the following substances will produce vasoconstriction in response to this process?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Renin does not cause vasoconstriction. Angiotensin I is biologically inactive. Aldosterone will increase blood pressure but does not have direct vasospastic effects.

choices.text: Zona reticularis of the adrenal gland
Zona glomerulosa of the adrenal gland
Zona fasciculata of the adrenal gland

questions.text: Which of the following is the main site of dehydroepiandrosterone release?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Adrenal cortex mnemonic: GFR - ACD

DHEA possesses some androgenic activity and is almost exclusively released from the adrenal gland.

questions.text: Which of the following is the equivalent of cardiac preload?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Preload is the same as end diastolic volume. When it is increased slightly there is an associated increase in cardiac output (Frank Starling principle). When it is markedly increased e.g. over 250ml then cardiac output falls.

choices.text: Binding of cell wall receptors and intracellular tyrosine kinase activation
Binding of intracellular receptors that migrate to the nucleus to then affect gene transcription
Activation of transmembrane tyrosine kinase systems to affect intranuclear gene transcription
Induces post translational modification of intracellular proteins
Direct binding of inflammatory cells inducing apoptosis

questions.text: Which of the following best accounts for the mechanism of action of glucocorticoids?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Binding of intracellular receptors that migrate to the nucleus to then affect gene transcription

questions.text: A 25 year old man is undergoing respiratory spirometry. He takes a maximal inspiration and maximally exhales. Which of the following measurements will best illustrate this process?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The maximum voluntary ventilation is the maximal ventilation over the course of 1 minute.

questions.text: Which of the following treatments is not utilized in the treatment of overactive bladder syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)

Overactive bladder syndrome is very common and first line management includes the use of anticholinergics and bladder drill whereby voiding is deferred.

Refractory cases can be treated with SNS or botulinum toxin injections. A Burch Colposuspension is used to treat stress urinary incontinence.

choices.text: It may occur as a result of mechanical bowel preparation
Chronic vomiting may increase renal potassium losses
It may be associated with aciduria

questions.text: Which of the following statements are not typically true in hypokalaemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)

Potassium depletion occurs either through the gastrointestinal tract or the kidney. Chronic vomiting in itself is less prone to induce potassium loss than diarrhoea as gastric secretions contain less potassium than those in the lower GI tract. If vomiting produces a metabolic alkalosis then renal potassium wasting may occur as potassium is excreted in preference to hydrogen ions. The converse may occur in potassium depletion resulting in acid urine.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman with thyroid cancer is admitted due to shortness of breath. What is the best investigation to assess for possible compression of the upper airways?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)

Flow volume loop is the best investigation to assess for possible compression of the upper airways. It is a graphical representation of the rate and volume of air flow during inhalation and exhalation, which can reveal any obstruction or narrowing of the airways. In the case of upper airway compression, the flow volume loop will show a flattened expiratory curve and decreased peak expiratory flow rate. Arterial blood gases, forced vital capacity, and transfer factor are not useful in assessing upper airway compression.
Flow volume loop

A normal flow volume loop is often described as a 'triangle on top of a semi circle'.

Flow volume loops are the most suitable way of assessing compression of the upper airway.

questions.text: What types of globin chains form fetal haemoglobin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Adult haemoglobin has 2 α- and 2 β-chains and fetal haemoglobin 2 α- and 2 γ-chains. The γ-chains allow a greater affinity for oxygen and thus enable the fetus to remove oxygen from the maternal circulation.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man has been admitted to the HDU following a left carotid endarterectomy. The surgeon has specified in the op note that the mean arterial pressure (MAP) must be kept above 70 mmHg. The patient’s BP is 120/60 mmHg, what is their MAP?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)

The MAP is calculated by the diastolic pressure (60 mmHg) + one-third of the pulse pressure. Pulse pressure is systolic – diastolic (120 – 60)/3 = 20 mmHg.

Therefore MAP is 60 + 20 = 80 mmHg.

questions.text: Proton pump inhibitors act on which proton pump to prevent acid secretion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

H+ ions are actively pumped from parietal cells and couple with Cl–cells (also actively pumped) to form HCl. By acting on the H+/K+ ATPase pump, it effectively cuts acid levels to near zero.

choices.text: Binding to fatty acids released by pancreatic enzymes
Calcium is lost via inflammatory fluid to third spaces
Calcium moving into cells due to metabolic acidosis
Decreased absorption due to decreased levels of digestive pancreatic enzymes
Increase in amylase, which binds to calcium

questions.text: Patients with acute pancreatitis may develop hypocalcaemia. What is the physiological explanation for this sign/symptom?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Fatty acids and calcium are deposited in the abdominal wall fat as ‘soap’.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man is admitted with jaundice. The bilirubin is raised. ALT is 3200 IU/L and the ALP is 600 IU/L. What is the most likely cause for his jaundice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)

The tests suggest a hepatocellular jaundice. This is indicated by the conjugated/unconjugated hyperbilirubinaemia due to decreased hepatocyte function and partial obstruction (note mildly elevated ALP). The ALT is grossly raised, reflecting liver cell damage.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man is admitted with jaundice and shivering. His urine is dark. There is no urobilinogen in the urine, the hyperbilirubinaemia is conjugated and the ALP is 1200 IU/L. What is the most likely cause for his jaundice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The urine is dark due to bilirubin excreted in the urine. The hyperbilirubinaemia is conjugated as the hepatocytes are still able to function. However, as bilirubin is not able to reach the intestine, there is no urobilinogen in the urine. The obstruction to biliary flow is shown by the grossly elevated ALP

questions.text: A normal adult requires 2000–2500 kcal/day energy. How much energy per gram does fat produce?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)

 Fat produces the most energy per gram. Carbohydrates produce 4.1 kcal/g and protein 5.3 kcal/g.

questions.text: A 33-year-old female is seen in A&E due to severe dehydration secondary to diarrhoea. She has admitted to abusing laxatives. What type of diarrhoea has she got?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

She is suffering from osmotic diarrhoea. This occurs when hypertonic substances, i.e. laxatives, cause large amounts of fluid to enter the bowel.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication to a pulmonary artery catheter?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A pulmonary artery catheter will cross the pulmonary and tricuspid valves and thus potentially damage a prosthetic valve. In endocarditis the catheter may dislodge valve vegetations; similarly with thrombus in the right heart. The catheter will not reach an aortic valve.

questions.text: Pulse oximeters use infrared light to assess arterial oxygen saturation by the differing absorption of oxygenated and deoxygenated haemoglobin. What specific wavelength of infrared light is used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The wavelength is 660–940 nm.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of reduced cardiac contractility?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

An increase in preload will cause an increase in cardiac contractility, whereas the rest will all result in a decrease. Starling’s law of the heart states that with an increase in end diastolic volume the stroke volume or energy of contraction increases.
